headline: Elliott Calls For Turnaround Plan At PepsiCo (PEP) To Unlock Shareholder Value
summary: PepsiCo (PEP) saw its shares rise 13% over the last quarter, highlighted by activist investor Elliott Investment Management's stake of $4 billion and proposals for growth enhancement. This influence was aligned with broader market trends, despite declining tech stocks dragging major indexes down by up to 2%. Additional factors perhaps bolstering PepsiCo's performance include strengthened partnerships, product launches, a robust dividend decision, and its strategic moves in debt financing...

headline: Big Food company shake-ups: Is it time to invest?
summary: Major food companies are getting shake-ups: Kraft Heinz (KHC) announced plans to split into two companies, activist investor Elliott Management is pushing for change at PepsiCo (PEP), and Nestlé (NESN.SW, NSRGY) fired its CEO. Crossmark Global Investments chief market strategist Victoria Fernandez and Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma join Opening Bid host Brian Sozzi to discuss whether these big moves indicate that it's time for investors to take a stake in Big Food. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid.

headline: Elliott Sends Presentation to Board of Directors of PepsiCo Inc.
summary: Elliott Investment Management L.P. ("Elliott"), which manages funds that together hold an investment of $4 billion in PepsiCo (NASDAQ: PEP) (the "Company" or "PepsiCo"), today sent a presentation and letter to the Company's Board of Directors. The materials set out PepsiCo's unique opportunity to re-accelerate growth and boost financial performance through greater focus, improved operations, strategic reinvestment and enhanced accountability.

The materials set out PepsiCo's unique opportunity to re-accelerate growth and boost financial performance through greater focus, improved operations, strategic reinvestment and enhanced accountability.

headline: Elliott takes aim at PepsiCo with $4 billion stake
summary: PepsiCo should conduct an operational review and put into place oversight and structure around reviews, the activist investor said in a presentation to the company's board.  The company has been tackling choppy demand for its snacks business, and working through shifting consumer preferences to healthier drinks and sodas by investing in beverages companies such as energy drink maker Celsius.  PepsiCo's stock, which has lost about a quarter of its value since hitting a record high in May 2023, jumped about 5% in premarket trading.

raw.headline: Elliott takes aim at PepsiCo with $4 billion stake

PepsiCo's stock, which has lost about a quarter of its value since hitting a record high in May 2023, jumped about 5% in premarket trading.

headline: Elliott Plans Major Activist Campaign at PepsiCo With $4 Billion Stake
summary: Activist investor Elliott Investment Management has built a roughly $4 billion stake in  PepsiCo  and plans to push the beverage and snacks giant to make changes to boost its sagging share price, according to people familiar with the matter.  PepsiCo has been struggling to win back soda drinkers after ceding market share to rivals.  Its food business, once an engine of growth for the company, is also under pressure.

raw.headline: Elliott Plans Major Activist Campaign at PepsiCo With $4 Billion Stake

PepsiCo has been struggling to win back soda drinkers after ceding market share to rivals.  Its food business, once an engine of growth for the company, is also under pressure.

headline: America Inc. Swaps Decades for Days in Rush to Commercial Paper
summary: Coca-Cola Co., PepsiCo Inc., Philip Morris International Inc. and Honeywell International Inc. have all tapped the market in recent months, selling billions worth of the short-term IOUs, which typically range in maturity from 30 to 90 days.  The renewed embrace of commercial paper is fueling the biggest expansion in the market since 2006, and underscores just how dramatically corporate America has been shifting its funding mix.  Faced with elevated interest rates and tariff turmoil, companies have moved to shore up cash buffers while avoiding locking in higher long-term borrowing costs, especially with potential Federal Reserve rate cuts on the horizon.
